subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Unicode Status
msgSnippet: ... OK. By the way how many QS fonts are there out there? Are they available in different styles? ... True. ... No, you would use ADO because that s the same
messageBody:
On 12 Apr 2013, at 19:11, oliver langan <oliver@...> wrote:

> I was involved with one of the proposals for Quickscript Unicode standardization. At the time I did not think that it made sense to re-use the code points which are common between Quickscript and Shavian, but over time I have come to see that it makes some sense.

OK. By the way how many QS fonts are there out there? Are they available in different styles?

> One benefit that I see is that converting between the two alphabets would be almost as easy as changing fonts.

True.

> Almost as easy, except for the key differences in orthography: Shavian uses two characters for schwa (ADO and UP), where Quickscript uses only UTTER: which code point do we use? Do we encode UTTER at both code points?

No, you would use ADO because that's the same character as UTTER.

> That would lead to the same word having two different (but visually indistinguishable) spellings, which would be problematic for machine translation.

No less problematic than theatre/theater or colour/color.

> As for the other differences, such as the EXCITE and EXAMINE characters, and LOCH, LLAN, or WHY: those are much more clearly extensions to the cod e points already provided by the Shavian unicode encoding.

Yes.

> The NAMER DOT can probably reuse the MIDDLE DOT character (U+00B7).

Yes.

> Did I miss any? It looks like Quickscript could be encoded in something like a half-dozen code points.

I should think so, yes.

Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com/
